awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: The role of genotype by social environment interactions on evolutionary trap susceptibility in groups of fruit flies
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Environmental change is happening faster than most species can adapt. Since behavioral responses are one of the most immediate reactions an animal can have toward changes in their environment, behavioral missteps can be especially harmful for the survival of many species. Evolutionary traps are a common type of behavioral pitfall, which happens when animals make decisions based on outdated or misleading information. However, the study of evolutionary traps is missing a critical aspect of most animals’ lives by ignoring the social setting in which species experience potential traps. This research will address this knowledge gap by studying how differences in both individual social behavior and social group composition influences whether animals fall for traps, and how this could lead to the rapid evolution of social traits. While the use of fruit flies in the lab enables rigorous examination of behavior and genetics, this research will have widespread implications because the dynamics studied are common across the animal kingdom. In addition, this project will support activities intended to increase the participation and retention of students and researchers from diverse backgrounds in the sciences.

This research will use a population of Drosophila melanogaster, the common fruit fly, with known genetic variation in social behaviors. Fruit flies encounter a common evolutionary trap in human-dominated landscapes: the apple cider vinegar trap. The first aim of the project is to quantify genetic variation in individual attraction to social cues associated with traps. The second aim is to measure the role of indirect genetic effects and emergent group traits on attraction to traps using group behavioral assays and social network analysis. Lastly, the third aim is to identify how traps could cause the evolution of social behaviors and other correlated traits using an artificial evolution experiment paired with RNA-sequencing to identify changes in gene expression. This project has great potential to add to the fields of evolutionary traps and social behavior by integrating the latest advances in behavioral research tools (i.e., state-of-the-art tracking software, social network theory) with quantitative genetics and genomics (i.e., next-generation sequencing), and providing training in these practices to the fellow. In addition, the fellow will establish a postdoctoral peer mentorship group, develop outreach materials with the Society for Conservation Biology and the Rice University Office of STEM Engagement, and mentor undergraduate researchers developing their own independent projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this postdoctoral fellowship project was to better understand how social behavior affects how animals navigate the novel challenges of the Anthropocene. Most animals do not live solitarily, and social environments can have a major impact on behavioral decision-making. This project focused on evolutionary traps, a type of behavioral pitfall in which animals make decisions based on cues that were once advantageous, but have recently shifted in association. Common evolutionary traps include fish eating plastic because it smells like a natural food source or insects laying eggs on glass because it looks like the surface of water. This project used controlled behavioral observations paired with an artificial evolution experiment to study how genetic variation in social information use drives differences in susceptibility to an evolutionary trap, and whether this has the potential to drive rapid evolutionary dynamics. To accomplish these aims, the fellow studied how social dynamics affect fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) falling for the everyday evolutionary trap of apple cider vinegar traps. Through these experiments, the fellow accomplished an additional aim of the award. That is, she received further training in the latest advances in evolutionary biology and genomics, which will help her form an interdisciplinary research program in the future.

 Over the course of the 2-year fellowship period, the fellow conducted eight experiments which are expected to result in four peer-reviewed manuscripts. Major findings from these experiments include that (1) fly susceptibility to traps increased with increasing numbers of already dead flies within that trap. This supports the hypothesis that social information can facilitate maladaptive decisions. Second, (2) variation in trap susceptibility was driven by genetic differences. Third (3), differences in trap susceptibility were also driven by sex, in that female flies were more trappable than males across many experiments. However, this effect was mediated by mating experience. That is, mated females were less susceptible to traps compared to their mated counterparts. This finding highlights the importance of accounting for sex and experience when assessing the role of social information use. Fourth (4), the fellow conducted an 18-month artificial evolution experiment, by which she exposed populations of flies to either a deadly apple cider vinegar trap or a harmless trap (i.e., a control). She then collected the offspring of the survivors to begin the next generation and repeat the experiment. Over the course of 22 generations, the flies under active selection became less susceptible to the apple cider vinegar trap compared to the control flies. Moreover, these differences in behavior were also reflected in the genetic signature of the last generation of flies through differential gene expression levels. This suggests that human action can cause rapid evolutionary change on a relatively short time scale.

In addition, the fellow also accomplished several broader impacts goals over the course of the fellowship. (1) The fellow mentored 12 undergraduate students through independent research courses, many over the course of multiple semesters. This includes a student who will be a co-author on a manuscript currently in review. In addition, (2) the fellow was an active member of the Rice University BioSciences Department Diversity Equity and Inclusion Committee. Actions in partnership with the committee included the organization of community events and development of outreach materials that celebrated intersectionality within biology. Lastly (3), the fellow organized a postdoctoral peer mentorship group, which met monthly for themed career development events.
